newsitem.title: ITALY: Italy pay talks adjourn, new meeting planned.
newsitem.headline: Italy pay talks adjourn, new meeting planned.

text.p: Talks between unions and employers in Italy's engineering and metalworking industry to try to end their pay dispute adjourned after more than three hours on Monday, one of the participants said.

Michele Figurati, director general of the employers' group Federmeccanica, said further talks would take place either later on Monday or on Tuesday. He spoke to reporters after meeting leaders of the FIOM, FIM and UIL unions.
"The meeting is over. We have adjourned until later, until this evening or tomorrow," Figurati said.
Monday's talks were the first for more than a month in a battle that has already seen three one-day strikes since it began last June when the sector's two-year contract agreement expired.

The talks took place at the Labour Ministry after Prime Minister Romano Prodi met leaders of Italy's three main labour confederations, CGIL, CISL and UIL, and the employers' umbrella group Confindustria to try to break the deadlock.

Italian television, in an unsourced report, said negotiators would look at a compromise deal involving monthly wage rises of 180,000 to 200,000 lire ($113-$144) and a 30-month contract period rather than the standard two years.
